content:
Can someone (AKA @Peter Scholze ) give me a little hint for the math proof of the dual snake lemma? The precise statement I am trying to prove is

variables (M M' N : system_of_complexes.{u}) (f : N ⟶ M) (g : M ⟶ M')

lemma weak_normed_snake_dual {k k' K K' r₁ r₂ : ℝ≥0}
  [hk : fact (1 ≤ k)] [hk' : fact (1 ≤ k')]
  {m : ℕ} {c₀ : ℝ≥0}
  (hM : M.is_weak_bounded_exact k K (m+1) c₀)
  (hM' : M'.is_weak_bounded_exact k' K' (m+1) c₀)
  (hM_adm : M.admissible)
  (hg : ∀ c i (x : M c i), ∥g x∥ ≤ r₁ * ∥x∥)
  (Hg : ∀ (c : ℝ≥0) [fact (c₀ ≤ c)] (i : ℕ) (hi : i ≤ m+1+1) (y : M' c i),
    ∃ (x : M c i), g x = y ∧ ∥x∥ ≤ r₂ * ∥y∥)
  (hg : ∀ c i, (f.apply : N c i ⟶ M c i).range = g.apply.ker)
  (hfker : system_of_complexes.is_kernel f) :
  N.is_weak_bounded_exact (k * k') (K' * (K + 1)) m c₀

(with the constants at the end that will be changed).

So we have g∙ ⁣:M∙→M′∙g^\bullet \colon M^\bullet \to M'^\bulletg∙:M∙→M′∙, of controlled norm and surjective, with N∙N^\bulletN∙ the system of kernels (let's ignore all the ccc, kckckc and so on, so no restriction). We want to prove that N∙N^\bulletN∙ is blah blah exact. Let n∈Nin \in N^in∈Ni, so n∈Min\in M^in∈Mi and I can use exactness of M∙M^\bulletM∙ to produce y∈Mi−1y \in M^{i-1}y∈Mi−1. I guess we need to look at what happens to z=g(y)z = g(y)z=g(y). My idea was to use exactness of M′M'M′ to produce z1∈M′i−2z_1 \in M'^{i-2}z1​∈M′i−2 and lift it to y1∈Mi−2y_1 \in M^{i-2}y1​∈Mi−2. The standard snake lemma tells me to look at y−d(y1)y - d(y_1)y−d(y1​), that is in the kernel of ggg and so it lies in Ni−1N^{i-1}Ni−1. But now this is not true anymore and I don't see how to produce an element in the kernel of ggg... thank's!!
Why is it not in the kernel of ggg? I'd have expected that this is true, at least after a further restriction?

Well, the image by ggg is z−d(z1)z-d(z_1)z−d(z1​). By construction of z1z_1z1​ we can control its norm using the norm of d(z)d(z)d(z) (again I am ignoring restrictions). Now the norm of d(z)d(z)d(z) is related to the norm of d(y)d(y)d(y), but I don't see why anything of these things should be 000.
Didn't you choose z1z_1z1​ so that z=d(z1)z=d(z_1)z=d(z1​)?
I have the feeling we really need to put all the ccc's in to resolve this
Let me write all the details

Let nk2c∈Nk2cin_{k^2c} \in N^i_{k^2c}nk2c​∈Nk2ci​, so nk2c∈Mk2cin_{k^2c}\in M^i_{k^2c}nk2c​∈Mk2ci​ and I can use exactness of M∙M^\bulletM∙ to produce ykc∈Mi−1y_{kc} \in M^{i-1}ykc​∈Mi−1 such that ∣∣nkc−d(ykc)∣∣≤K∣∣d(nk2c)∣∣+ε||n_{kc}-d(y_{kc})|| \leq K || d(n_{k^2c})|| + \varepsilon∣∣nkc​−d(ykc​)∣∣≤K∣∣d(nk2c​)∣∣+ε. Let zkc=g(ykc)z_{kc} = g(y_{kc})zkc​=g(ykc​). By exactness of M′M'M′ we can find z1,c∈Mc′i−2z_{1,c} \in M'^{i-2}_cz1,c​∈Mc′i−2​ such that ∣∣zc−d(z1,c)∣∣≤K′∣∣d(zkc)∣∣+ε||z_{c}-d(z_{1,c})|| \leq K' || d(z_{kc})|| + \varepsilon∣∣zc​−d(z1,c​)∣∣≤K′∣∣d(zkc​)∣∣+ε. We can lift it to y1,c∈Mci−2y_{1,c} \in M^{i-2}_cy1,c​∈Mci−2​. Let consider yc−d(y1,c)y_{c}-d(y_{1,c})yc​−d(y1,c​). Its image by ggg is zc−d(z1,c)z_{c}-d(z_{1,c})zc​−d(z1,c​) that satisfies ∣∣zc−d(z1,c)∣∣≤K′∣∣d(zkc)∣∣+ε||z_{c}-d(z_{1,c})|| \leq K' || d(z_{kc})|| + \varepsilon ∣∣zc​−d(z1,c​)∣∣≤K′∣∣d(zkc​)∣∣+ε. Let yc′∈Mci−1y'_c \in M^{i-1}_cyc′​∈Mci−1​ be a lift of zc−d(z1,c)z_{c}-d(z_{1,c})zc​−d(z1,c​) with norm smaller than r2∣∣zc−d(z1,c)∣∣r_2||z_{c}-d(z_{1,c})||r2​∣∣zc​−d(z1,c​)∣∣. By construction yc−d(y1,c)−yc′∈Ni−1y_{c}-d(y_{1,c})-y'_c \in N^{i-1}yc​−d(y1,c​)−yc′​∈Ni−1. We need to control ∣∣nc−d(yc−d(y1,c)−yc′)∣∣=∣∣nc−d(yc−yc′)∣∣||n_c - d( y_{c}-d(y_{1,c})-y'_c )|| = ||n_c - d( y_{c}-y'_c )||∣∣nc​−d(yc​−d(y1,c​)−yc′​)∣∣=∣∣nc​−d(yc​−yc′​)∣∣
Ah!! You are using weak exactness here! Actually, we only need the lemma in a situation where everything is complete, and anyways we know strong exactness
I'd guess one should also be able to prove it with weak exactness... let me try to do it on paper, but feel free to write up the version with strong exactness
OK, this eliminates the epsilon, but still I have ∣∣zc−d(z1,c)∣∣≤K′∣∣d(zkc)∣∣||z_{c}-d(z_{1,c})|| \leq K' || d(z_{kc})|| ∣∣zc​−d(z1,c​)∣∣≤K′∣∣d(zkc​)∣∣. Is d(zkc)=0d(z_{kc})=0d(zkc​)=0?
Hmm, maybe trivially yes
Ah sorry I was starting with nk2cn_{k^2c}nk2c​ in the kernel of ddd, in which case this would be trivially zero
OK, let me try to write down an actual argument...
maybe even for weak exactness (for consistency's sake)

By the way, if you have some yyy such that g(y)g(y)g(y) is small, as opposed to exactly 000, you can always modify it by changing by a small lift of g(y)g(y)g(y): This shows that there is some y′y'y′ close to yyy with g(y′)=0g(y')=0g(y′)=0.

So coming back to the above, one ought to be able to prove that zc−d(z1,c)z_c-d(z_{1,c})zc​−d(z1,c​) has norm bounded in terms of the norm of d(nk2c)d(n_{k^2c})d(nk2c​). Together with what I said in my previous message, this should be enough to conclude.
Ah yes, this looks promising. Let me check
How does it look?

So far I am here

Let nk2c∈Nk2cin_{k^2c} \in N^i_{k^2c}nk2c​∈Nk2ci​, so nk2c∈Mk2cin_{k^2c}\in M^i_{k^2c}nk2c​∈Mk2ci​ and I can use exactness of M∙M^\bulletM∙ to produce ykc∈Mi−1y_{kc} \in M^{i-1}ykc​∈Mi−1 such that ∣∣nkc−d(ykc)∣∣≤K∣∣d(nk2c)∣∣+ε||n_{kc}-d(y_{kc})|| \leq K || d(n_{k^2c})|| + \varepsilon∣∣nkc​−d(ykc​)∣∣≤K∣∣d(nk2c​)∣∣+ε. Let zkc=g(ykc)z_{kc} = g(y_{kc})zkc​=g(ykc​). By exactness of M′M'M′ we can find z1,c∈Mc′i−2z_{1,c} \in M'^{i-2}_cz1,c​∈Mc′i−2​ such that ∣∣zc−d(z1,c)∣∣≤K′∣∣d(zkc)∣∣+ε||z_{c}-d(z_{1,c})|| \leq K' || d(z_{kc})|| + \varepsilon∣∣zc​−d(z1,c​)∣∣≤K′∣∣d(zkc​)∣∣+ε. We can lift z1,cz_{1,c}z1,c​ to y1,c∈Mci−2y_{1,c} \in M^{i-2}_cy1,c​∈Mci−2​. Let consider yc−d(y1,c)y_{c}-d(y_{1,c})yc​−d(y1,c​), whose image by ggg is zc−d(z1,c)z_{c}-d(z_{1,c})zc​−d(z1,c​). Let yc′∈Mci−1y'_c \in M^{i-1}_cyc′​∈Mci−1​ be a lift of zc−d(z1,c)z_{c}-d(z_{1,c})zc​−d(z1,c​) with norm smaller than r2∣∣zc−d(z1,c)∣∣r_2||z_{c}-d(z_{1,c})||r2​∣∣zc​−d(z1,c​)∣∣. By construction yc−d(y1,c)−yc′∈Ni−1y_{c}-d(y_{1,c})-y'_c \in N^{i-1}yc​−d(y1,c​)−yc′​∈Ni−1. We need to control
∣∣nc−d(yc−d(y1,c)−yc′)∣∣≤∣∣nc−d(yc)∣∣+∣∣d(yc′)∣∣≤∣∣nc−d(yc)∣∣+∣∣yc′∣∣≤∣∣nc−d(yc)∣∣+r2∣∣zc−d(z1,c)∣∣≤∣∣nc−d(yc)∣∣+r2(K′∣∣d(zkc)∣∣+ε)≤∣∣nkc−d(ykc)∣∣+r2(K′∣∣d(zkc)∣∣+ε)≤K∣∣d(nk2c)∣∣+ε+r2(K′∣∣d(zkc)∣∣+ε)=K∣∣d(nk2c)∣∣+ε+r2(K′∣∣d(g(ykc))∣∣+ε)=K∣∣d(nk2c)∣∣+ε+r2(K′∣∣g(d(ykc))∣∣+ε)=K∣∣d(nk2c)∣∣+ε+r2(K′∣∣g(nkc−d(ykc))∣∣+ε) ||n_c - d( y_{c}-d(y_{1,c})-y'_c )|| \leq \\ || n_c - d( y_{c})|| + ||d( y'_c )|| \leq \\ || n_c - d( y_{c})|| + || y'_c || \leq \\ || n_c - d( y_{c})|| + r_2||z_{c}-d(z_{1,c})|| \leq \\ || n_c - d( y_{c})|| + r_2(K'|| d(z_{kc})|| + \varepsilon) \leq \\ ||n_{kc}-d(y_{kc})|| + r_2(K'|| d(z_{kc})|| + \varepsilon) \leq \\ K || d(n_{k^2c})|| + \varepsilon + r_2(K'|| d(z_{kc})|| + \varepsilon) = \\ K || d(n_{k^2c})|| + \varepsilon + r_2(K'|| d(g(y_{kc}))|| + \varepsilon) = \\ K || d(n_{k^2c})|| + \varepsilon + r_2(K'|| g(d(y_{kc}))|| + \varepsilon) = \\ K || d(n_{k^2c})|| + \varepsilon + r_2(K'|| g(n_{kc} - d(y_{kc}))|| + \varepsilon) ∣∣nc​−d(yc​−d(y1,c​)−yc′​)∣∣≤∣∣nc​−d(yc​)∣∣+∣∣d(yc′​)∣∣≤∣∣nc​−d(yc​)∣∣+∣∣yc′​∣∣≤∣∣nc​−d(yc​)∣∣+r2​∣∣zc​−d(z1,c​)∣∣≤∣∣nc​−d(yc​)∣∣+r2​(K′∣∣d(zkc​)∣∣+ε)≤∣∣nkc​−d(ykc​)∣∣+r2​(K′∣∣d(zkc​)∣∣+ε)≤K∣∣d(nk2c​)∣∣+ε+r2​(K′∣∣d(zkc​)∣∣+ε)=K∣∣d(nk2c​)∣∣+ε+r2​(K′∣∣d(g(ykc​))∣∣+ε)=K∣∣d(nk2c​)∣∣+ε+r2​(K′∣∣g(d(ykc​))∣∣+ε)=K∣∣d(nk2c​)∣∣+ε+r2​(K′∣∣g(nkc​−d(ykc​))∣∣+ε).

Now I don't see immediatly how to go from the norm of ykcy_{kc}ykc​ to the norm of d(nk2c)d(n_{k^2c})d(nk2c​), but I was having lunch, and I didn't check the computations.

I think you need to be more careful with the estimate of ∣∣d(zkc)∣∣||d(z_{kc})||∣∣d(zkc​)∣∣: Use rather d(zkc)=d(g(ykc))=g(d(ykc))=g(d(ykc)−nkc)d(z_{kc})=d(g(y_{kc})) = g(d(y_{kc})) = g(d(y_{kc})-n_{kc})d(zkc​)=d(g(ykc​))=g(d(ykc​))=g(d(ykc​)−nkc​) and the estimate on ∣∣nkc−d(ykc)∣∣||n_{kc}-d(y_{kc})||∣∣nkc​−d(ykc​)∣∣.

OK, so we have
∣∣nc−d(yc−d(y1,c)−yc′)∣∣≤∣∣nc−d(yc)∣∣+∣∣d(yc′)∣∣≤∣∣nc−d(yc)∣∣+∣∣yc′∣∣≤∣∣nc−d(yc)∣∣+r2∣∣zc−d(z1,c)∣∣≤∣∣nc−d(yc)∣∣+r2(K′∣∣d(zkc)∣∣+ε)≤∣∣nkc−d(ykc)∣∣+r2(K′∣∣d(zkc)∣∣+ε)≤K∣∣d(nk2c)∣∣+ε+r2(K′∣∣d(zkc)∣∣+ε)=K∣∣d(nk2c)∣∣+ε+r2(K′∣∣d(g(ykc))∣∣+ε)=K∣∣d(nk2c)∣∣+ε+r2(K′∣∣g(d(ykc))∣∣+ε)=K∣∣d(nk2c)∣∣+ε+r2(K′∣∣g(nkc−d(ykc))∣∣+ε)≤K∣∣d(nk2c)∣∣+ε+r2(K′r1∣∣nkc−d(ykc)∣∣+ε)≤K∣∣d(nk2c)∣∣+ε+r2(K′r1K∣∣d(nk2c)∣∣+ε)=∣∣d(nk2c)∣∣(K+r2r1KK′)+ε(1+r2) ||n_c - d( y_{c}-d(y_{1,c})-y'_c )|| \leq \\ || n_c - d( y_{c})|| + ||d( y'_c )|| \leq \\ || n_c - d( y_{c})|| + || y'_c || \leq \\ || n_c - d( y_{c})|| + r_2||z_{c}-d(z_{1,c})|| \leq \\ || n_c - d( y_{c})|| + r_2(K'|| d(z_{kc})|| + \varepsilon) \leq \\ ||n_{kc}-d(y_{kc})|| + r_2(K'|| d(z_{kc})|| + \varepsilon) \leq \\ K || d(n_{k^2c})|| + \varepsilon + r_2(K'|| d(z_{kc})|| + \varepsilon) = \\ K || d(n_{k^2c})|| + \varepsilon + r_2(K'|| d(g(y_{kc}))|| + \varepsilon) = \\ K || d(n_{k^2c})|| + \varepsilon + r_2(K'|| g(d(y_{kc}))|| + \varepsilon) = \\ K || d(n_{k^2c})|| + \varepsilon + r_2(K'|| g(n_{kc} - d(y_{kc}))|| + \varepsilon) \leq \\ K || d(n_{k^2c})|| + \varepsilon + r_2(K'r_1|| n_{kc} - d(y_{kc})|| + \varepsilon) \leq \\ K || d(n_{k^2c})|| + \varepsilon + r_2(K'r_1K || d(n_{k^2c})|| + \varepsilon) = \\ || d(n_{k^2c})||(K + r_2r_1KK') + \varepsilon(1+r_2) ∣∣nc​−d(yc​−d(y1,c​)−yc′​)∣∣≤∣∣nc​−d(yc​)∣∣+∣∣d(yc′​)∣∣≤∣∣nc​−d(yc​)∣∣+∣∣yc′​∣∣≤∣∣nc​−d(yc​)∣∣+r2​∣∣zc​−d(z1,c​)∣∣≤∣∣nc​−d(yc​)∣∣+r2​(K′∣∣d(zkc​)∣∣+ε)≤∣∣nkc​−d(ykc​)∣∣+r2​(K′∣∣d(zkc​)∣∣+ε)≤K∣∣d(nk2c​)∣∣+ε+r2​(K′∣∣d(zkc​)∣∣+ε)=K∣∣d(nk2c​)∣∣+ε+r2​(K′∣∣d(g(ykc​))∣∣+ε)=K∣∣d(nk2c​)∣∣+ε+r2​(K′∣∣g(d(ykc​))∣∣+ε)=K∣∣d(nk2c​)∣∣+ε+r2​(K′∣∣g(nkc​−d(ykc​))∣∣+ε)≤K∣∣d(nk2c​)∣∣+ε+r2​(K′r1​∣∣nkc​−d(ykc​)∣∣+ε)≤K∣∣d(nk2c​)∣∣+ε+r2​(K′r1​K∣∣d(nk2c​)∣∣+ε)=∣∣d(nk2c​)∣∣(K+r2​r1​KK′)+ε(1+r2​).
That's what we wanted, right?

Yes, this proves

variables (M M' N : system_of_complexes.{u}) (f : N ⟶ M) (g : M ⟶ M')

lemma weak_normed_snake_dual {k k' K K' r₁ r₂ : ℝ≥0}
  [hk : fact (1 ≤ k)] [hk' : fact (1 ≤ k')]
  {m : ℕ} {c₀ : ℝ≥0}
  (hM : M.is_weak_bounded_exact k K (m+1) c₀)
  (hM' : M'.is_weak_bounded_exact k' K' (m+1) c₀)
  (hM_adm : M.admissible)
  (hg : ∀ c i (x : M c i), ∥g x∥ ≤ r₁ * ∥x∥)
  (Hg : ∀ (c : ℝ≥0) [fact (c₀ ≤ c)] (i : ℕ) (hi : i ≤ m+1+1) (y : M' c i),
    ∃ (x : M c i), g x = y ∧ ∥x∥ ≤ r₂ * ∥y∥)
  (hg : ∀ c i, (f.apply : N c i ⟶ M c i).range = g.apply.ker)
  (hfker : system_of_complexes.is_kernel f) :
  N.is_weak_bounded_exact (k * k') (K + r₁ * r₂ * K * K') m c₀

I am 99% sure there will be no Lean problems (same for the strong version if we need it).
Wow! That went pretty fast! I remember that the original snake lemma took a bit more work
you mean the thing you proved as your first lean project ever in about 2018?
No, I meant the one in LTE
The original normed snake
Oh OK :-) I could imagine that Riccardo now was faster than you in 2018 :-)
What I proved in 2018 was the five lemma, and it also took some time (-;
Well, I have the math proof, not yet the Lean proof...
I will try to do it today
And the "subspace norm" is easier than the quotient norm...

@Johan Commelin With the new complexes, what is the strategy to deal with the following situation?

Let M∙M^\bulletM∙ a complex that is bla bla exact and i≤mi \leq mi≤m. I have x∈Mix \in M^ix∈Mi, and I use exactness to build an element y∈Mi−1y \in M^{i-1}y∈Mi−1. Now I want to consider x+d(y)x + d(y)x+d(y), where the ddd is the one given in the definition of exactness (I mean, with i and j). If i=0i=0i=0 then y∈M0y \in M^0y∈M0, but d(y)d(y)d(y) is still in M1M^1M1. Should I do a by_cases and avoid the addition if i=0i=0i=0? (This is going to work since anyway y=0y=0y=0 if i=0i=0i=0)
(deleted)
You can use the X_prev construction which gives the zero object if there is no previous object

I don't think I can chose, yyy is given by

def is_bounded_exact
  (k K : ℝ≥0) (m : ℕ) [hk : fact (1 ≤ k)] (c₀ : ℝ≥0) : Prop :=
∀ c (hc : fact (c₀ ≤ c)) i (hi : i ≤ m) (x : C (k * c) i),
∃ (i₀ j : ℕ) (hi₀ : i₀ = i - 1) (hj : i + 1 = j)
  (y : C c i₀), ∥res x - C.d _ _ y∥ ≤ K * ∥C.d i j x∥

So it will be in M0M^0M0 if i=0i=0i=0. But C.d _ _ y = 0 in this case, since C.d 0 0 = 0,
I see... So to really use the new complexes API, I think this definition might need to be changed
I don't know what's best given the new complexes.
But my idea was indeed that you would get something in degree 0-1 = 0 and then use that C.d 0 0 = 0. So all should be well.
Ah wait, now I can write d _ _ y instead of just d y, and with the correct _ this should work
Hmm, it doesn't work: I really want to consider d i' i'+1 y, that is given by the exactness condition, and the idea is to add x to this. I guess that a by_cases will work :grimacing:
@Riccardo Brasca You can do cases i instead of by_cases.
That might save you nasty rewrites.
Yes, but then I will have i.succ everywhere... I will see

In any case the beginning of the proof is here
https://github.com/leanprover-community/lean-liquid/blob/normed_snake_dual/src/normed_snale_dual.lean

There are a lot of sorry in the calc bloc, but they should be easy

Riccardo Brasca said:

Yes, but then I will have i.succ everywhere... I will see

I hope dsimp only [nat.succ_eq_add_one] will fix that.
But by_cases is also an option, and then subst.
I only need i ≠ 0 to rewrite i' + 1 = i (here i' = i - 1) inside a differential. I was afraid of "motive is not type correct", but it worked
@Riccardo Brasca You've got snale in your file name :stuck_out_tongue_wink: :snail:

By the way, I think I've got the complexes ready to which we want to apply this lemma.
We want to prove that the complex on the left ("the kernel") is

((thm95.double_complex BD.data c_ r r' V Λ M (N c' r r' m)).col j).is_weak_bounded_exact (k₁ m) (K₁ m) m (c₀ m Λ)

But the constants (k₁ m) (K₁ m) still have to be defined, and we can basically make them whatever we want/need (-;
The need to be "large" in some sense. But we can give them a nice definitional shape if that is convenient.
Feel free to merge into master the branch normed_snake_dual, the statement should be correct.
Also the structure of the proof is there, I am killing all the mini sorry in the calc bloc to check that I didn't made stupid mistakes on paper

normed_snake_dual is now in master. The file contain 10 sorry at the moment.

The first one, in admissible_of_kernel said that a system of complexes, isomorphic to the kernel of a morphism of system of complexes with admissible domain, is admissible. This is obvious since we can compute the norm after applying the morphism. Is this a special case of something already there?

The next 8 sorry are trivial, 0 < 37+ε ^ 37 if 0 < ε.

The last one is the only one not completely easy: it is the theorem in the case i=0. The same proof does not literally apply, but indeed it should be easier. I will do it tomorrow, trying to avoid code duplication as much as possible.
Also, the giant calc should be golfed, there are lines, whose proof is rfl, that I don't understand why I need them.
If we had a proof of the snail lemma for free that would be impressive https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jpaa.2016.06.001
Also the sorry corresponding to i=0 is now reduced to an (easy) inequality in ℝ. I pushed this to the branch normed_snake_dual, I will put it in master tomorrow.
Thanks @Riccardo Brasca, that's great work!
I don't think admissible_of_kernel follows from something that we already have.
Now all the sorry are completely trivial. I have some teaching stuff to do today, but I will finish it before the weekend.

BTW, to use lemmas like normed_group_hom.map_sub I had to change f m to f.apply m (here f : M ⟶ N is a morphism of system of complexes and m: M c i for some c and i). I realize that I was maybe a bit to fast with suggesting to abstract away r1 and r2 into constants.
How hard do you think it would be to replace the assumption

(Hg : ∀ (c : ℝ≥0) [fact (c₀ ≤ c)] (i : ℕ) (hi : i ≤ a + 1 + 1) (y : P c i),
    ∃ (x : N c i), g x = y ∧ ∥x∥ ≤ r₂ * ∥y∥)

with

(Hg : ∀ (c : ℝ≥0) [fact (c₀ ≤ c)] (i : ℕ) (hi : i ≤ a + 1 + 1) (\eps : \nnreal) (h\eps : 0 < \eps) (y : P c i),
    ∃ (x : N c i), g x = y ∧ ∥x∥ ≤ (r₂ + \eps) * ∥y∥)

I guess we don't need the strong version (although for this part of the argument, I think it wouldn't matter -- all argument should directly give the strong version here, and the constants would also be the same. But in the end we are just trying to get input into 9.6, and there only weak exactness is required).
What constant do you need? Now the result is that the kernel is K + r₁ * r₂ * K * K'-exact, with r₂ arbitrary. If ε is big then it will change the constant for sure.
Hmm... the point is that 9.2 gives us this "forall \eps > 0, the norm is bounded by r_2 + \eps"
For some r_2
Well, to be more precise: "forall \eps > 0, there exists a y such that ... , ..., the norm is bounded by r2 + \eps"
So in the proof of dual snake you can choose y such that \eps is as small as you want it to be

I see. This gives

(Hg : ∀ (c : ℝ≥0) [fact (c₀ ≤ c)] (i : ℕ) (hi : i ≤ a + 1 + 1) (y : P c i),
    ∃ (x : N c i), g x = y ∧ ∥x∥ ≤ (r₂ + 1) * ∥y∥)

So we automatically get K + r₁ * (r₂ + 1) * K * K'-exactness. If we want K + r₁ * r₂ * K * K'-exactness I have to check the proof, but I think it's OK.

Sounds good!
If we need the strong version I have proved it (it took 10 minutes, the same exact proof works, much easier then the cokernel case)
@Riccardo Brasca with the + \eps in the assumption?

variables (M N P : system_of_complexes.{u}) (f : M ⟶ N) (g : N ⟶ P)

lemma normed_snake_dual {k k' K K' r₁ r₂ : ℝ≥0}
  [hk : fact (1 ≤ k)] [hk' : fact (1 ≤ k')]
  {a : ℕ} {c₀ : ℝ≥0}
  (hN : N.is_bounded_exact k K (a + 1) c₀)
  (hP : P.is_bounded_exact k' K' (a + 1) c₀)
  (hN_adm : N.admissible)
  (hgnorm : ∀ c i (x : N c i), ∥g x∥ ≤ r₁ * ∥x∥)
  (Hg : ∀ (c : ℝ≥0) [fact (c₀ ≤ c)] (i : ℕ) (hi : i ≤ a + 1 + 1) (y : P c i),
    ∃ (x : N c i), g x = y ∧ ∥x∥ ≤ r₂ * ∥y∥)
  (hg : ∀ c i, (f.apply : M c i ⟶ N c i).range = g.apply.ker)
  (hfiso : ∀ c i, @isometry (M c i) (N c i) _ _ f.apply) :
  M.is_bounded_exact (k * k') (K + r₁ * r₂ * K * K') a c₀ :=

Is the same as the weak one. If you are ready to lose something in the constant at the end just use you assumption with ε and you will get M.is_bounded_exact (k * k') (K + r₁ * (r₂ + 1) * K * K') a c₀
If we really need M.is_bounded_exact (k * k') (K + r₁ * r₂ * K * K') a c₀ no problem, I will think about it
I don't think it's an urgent problem. But it is of course nice to optimize the constants.
(Now I need to run. I'll be gone for an hour or two. Ciao.)

My impression is that we can (easily ) prove that a system of complexes that is K + ε- weak exact for all 0 < ε is K- weak exact, so taking a sufficiently small ε in your Hg we would get K + r₁ * r₂ * K * K'-weak exactness.
For strong exactness, we can obtain K + r₁ * r₂ * K * K' + ε-exactness, but to get rid of the ε we have to modify the proof (I don't think K+ε-exactness implies K-exactness in general).
Yeah, I think in the strong version, with Johan's hypothesis, one will lose some ϵ\epsilonϵ in the conclusion.
Don't worry about any of this; we're having doubly-exponential growth at least in other parts of the argument...

I've golfed the proof a little bit and pushed to master. Now normed_snake_dual contains complete proofs of the dual weak snake lemma and of the dual strong snake lemma. The file is quite slow, but I guess we just use it and forget about it. (If we want to improve the speed, there are lemmas (proved by ring) that are used in both proof and that can be proved only once)
